title: Achalasia
diagnosis_topic: Failure of lower esophageal sphincter relaxation and absence of peristalsis
setup_script: A 45-year-old woman reports progressive difficulty swallowing both solids and liquids over several months. She experiences regurgitation of undigested food and nocturnal cough.

dynamic_flow.reply: Dysphagia to solids and liquids, regurgitation of saliva and undigested food, weight loss of 10 lbs; denies heartburn.
Shows dilated esophagus with bird-beak tapering at gastroesophageal junction and poor emptying.
Demonstrates increased lower esophageal sphincter pressure with incomplete relaxation and absence of peristaltic waves.
Rules out pseudoachalasia from malignancy; no obstructing lesion found.
Pneumatic dilation, laparoscopic Heller myotomy with partial fundoplication, peroral endoscopic myotomy (POEM) or botulinum toxin injection.
Suitable for younger patients; plan laparoscopy with Dor fundoplication to prevent reflux.
Consider repeated botulinum toxin injections or pneumatic dilation despite higher recurrence.
Progressive esophageal dilation and risk of aspiration pneumonia increase.
Monitor for GERD symptoms; prescribe proton pump inhibitors; gradual diet progression.
Periodic assessment of symptoms and potential need for additional interventions.
Encourage small frequent meals and elevation of head during sleep; avoid lying down after eating.

critical_decision_points: Diagnosis of achalasia using barium swallow, manometry and endoscopy
Discussion of therapeutic options including myotomy, dilation and POEM
Selection of appropriate treatment based on patient age and comorbidities
Postoperative management to prevent reflux and monitor for recurrence
Patient education on lifestyle modifications and follow-up
